versionNotes: Forces connection between self-knowledge and design decisions
title: Design Decision Analysis
description: This activity helps you see the CONNECTION between what you know about yourself and how that shaped your design.

settings.skipNudgeMessage: This question prepares you for the demo. Are you sure you want to skip?

questions.prompt: Two students describe why they chose their experiment approach. Which shows deeper STAKEHOLDER knowledge (knowledge of themselves)?
options: "I built a habit tracker because habit trackers help with habits."
"I built a morning-only reminder because I know I ignore notifications after noon — I've trained myself to dismiss them."
"I built the simplest version possible to test my idea quickly."
"I built what the AI suggested because it seemed reasonable."
questions.hint: Which answer shows something the student KNOWS about themselves that shaped the design?
questions.explanation: Option B shows specific self-knowledge: 'I ignore notifications after noon.' This isn't a generic best practice — it's something THIS person knows about THEMSELVES.

questions.prompt: What's wrong with generic advice like 'use a to-do list app' as a solution?
options: To-do list apps don't work for anyone
It's not technically sophisticated enough
It doesn't account for YOUR specific friction points and patterns
AI could suggest something better
questions.hint: Think about why the same solution might work for one person and fail for another.
questions.explanation: Generic solutions ignore stakeholder context. A to-do list might help someone who forgets tasks but HARM someone who feels overwhelmed by seeing all their tasks at once.

questions.prompt: What is ONE thing you know about yourself that shaped your experiment design? Something a generic solution wouldn't account for. Be specific — not 'I procrastinate' but 'I procrastinate specifically when...'
questions.placeholder: Example: I know that I check my phone first thing when I wake up, and once I'm on my phone I lose 30+ minutes to scrolling. This shaped my experiment because...

questions.prompt:
A student's 5 Whys journey:
• Stated: 'I want to exercise more'
• Why 1: 'Because I feel unhealthy'
• Why 2: 'Because I never work out'
• Why 3: 'Because by evening I'm too tired'
• Why 4: 'Because I don't have a transition ritual from work to personal time'
• Why 5: 'Because I work until I crash'

Which 'why' reveals the DESIGN OPPORTUNITY?
options: Why 1 — feeling unhealthy is the core motivation
Why 2 — the behavior they want to change
Why 4 — the missing transition ritual is something they can design
Why 5 — working until crashing is the root problem
questions.hint: A design opportunity is something you can CHANGE — not just 'try harder.'
questions.explanation: Why 4 reveals a design opportunity: a missing transition ritual. This is something the student can CREATE — a system change, not willpower.

questions.prompt: What was your STATED problem when you started Sprint 1? What did you DISCOVER was the REAL problem underneath? What did you know about yourself that helped you see the difference?
questions.placeholder:
Stated problem: I wanted to...
Real problem I discovered: The actual barrier was...
I knew this because I noticed that I...

questions.prompt: Why is 'good enough' different for every stakeholder?
options: Some people have higher standards than others
Different stakeholders have different contexts, constraints, and what 'solved' means for their specific situation
It's not different — there's an objective standard of quality
Stakeholders just have different preferences
questions.hint: Think about how YOUR definition of 'solved' might be different from someone else solving a similar problem.
questions.explanation: 'Good enough' is stakeholder-specific. For someone with ADHD, a feature-rich habit tracker might be overwhelming. For a data-driven person, a simple tracker might feel insufficient.

questions.prompt: What does 'solved' look like for YOUR challenge? Why is this YOUR definition and not someone else's?
questions.placeholder: For me, 'solved' means... This is MY definition because I know that I...

questions.prompt:
Compare these two friction analyses:

A: "I forget to do it."

B: "I forget to do it specifically when I'm tired after work, and tiredness makes me dismiss reminders instead of acting on them."

What makes B better?
options: B is longer and more detailed
B shows WHEN and WHY the friction happens, revealing what to design around
B mentions tiredness, which is more relatable
B explains the person's feelings more
questions.hint: Which analysis gives you something specific to DESIGN around?
questions.explanation: B reveals stakeholder-specific friction: tired + evening + dismisses reminders. This is designable! Maybe the experiment needs morning reminders, or pre-commitment before tiredness.

questions.prompt: What's the friction point where you typically fail? What do you know about yourself that explains WHY you fail there? (Not just 'I forget' — what's underneath?)
questions.placeholder: My friction point is... I know this happens because I've noticed that I...

Draft your answer to the required demo question:

'Walk through your 5 Whys chain. At which why did you find a design opportunity?'

Include:
• What you thought was the problem
• What you discovered underneath
• At which 'why' you found the design opportunity
• How knowing yourself helped you see it
